description: From Middle English puttock, puttok, potok, puttoc, of uncertain origin; perhaps representing an unattested Old English *putta (“hawk”)  +‎ -ock; or perhaps from Old English *pūthafoc (literally “pout-hawk”), equivalent to pout (“a kind of fish”) +‎ hawk. Compare also pout (“a young bird”), poult.

entries.meaning: (now Britain regional) Any of several birds of prey including the red kite, buzzard or marsh harrier
(by extension) A rapacious person who preys on the defenseless.
